Answers: Because Jerry was ill.

Questions: How long wasn’t Beauty put in the carriage?
Answers: For three days.

Questions: What did the doctor advise Jerry ?
Answers: He advised him not to drive taxis any more

Questions: Why did the doctor advise Jerry not to drive taxis?
Answers: To stay healthy.

Questions: What did Polly do to help her ill husband?
Answers: She wrote to Mrs. Fowler to ask for work for Jerry.

Questions: What did Fowler write back?
Answers: She said that she wanted Jerry to work for her.

Questions: Where would Jerry and family live?
Answers: In a cottage near Fowler’s house.

Questions: What was the bad news for Beauty?
Answers: Jerry would work for Mrs. Fowler.

Questions: What would happen to Beauty when Jerry worked for Fowler?
Answers: He would be sold.

Questions: To whom was Beauty sold?
Answers: To a taxi driver called Skinner.

Questions: Who was Skinner?
Answers: He was the same man who made Ginger weak and sad.

Questions: How was Beauty’s life with Skinner?
Answers: It was very bad as he worked for 7 days without rest or enough food.

Questions: Where was Beauty put at the market?
Answers: He was put with old and ill-looking horses.

Questions: Why did Beauty think that no one would buy him?
Answers: Because he became old and ill.

Questions: How were the people who looked at Beauty?
Answers: Most of Them were poor and wanted a horse for little money.

Questions: Who also looked at Beauty?
Answers: An old farmer and his grandson.

Questions: What did the boy say about Beauty?
Answers: He said that he looked kind and intelligent.

Questions: What did the old farmer say?
Answers: He said that the horse was old.

Questions: What did the man who took Beauty to the market say?
Answers: He said that Beauty was not too old and was used to drive taxis.

Questions: How would Beauty be a good horse again?
Answers: With a little rest.

Questions: Why was the grandson delighted?
Answers: Because his grandfather decided to buy Beauty.

Questions: What was the new owner called?
Answers: He was called Mr. Thoroughgood.

Questions: Where did Mr. Thoroughgood take Beauty?
Answers: To a large field where he was given good food.

Questions: What was the grandson called?
Answers: He was called Willie.

Questions: When did Beauty become well?
Answers: When spring came.

Questions: Did Mr. Thoroughgood change his mind about Beauty?
Answers: Yes, and said that he was pleased because Beauty was a good horse.

Questions: What did the old farmer want?
Answers: He wanted to find a place for Beauty to work.

Questions: Where did the old farmer take Beauty?
Answers: To the home of Miss Blomefield and her two sisters.

Questions: What did Miss Blomefield need?
Answers: She needed a new horse.

Questions: What did Miss Blomefield notice about Beauty?
Answers: He didn’t look well from his knees.

Questions: What did the farmer say about Beauty’s past?
Answers: He said he had a difficult past and she would find a better horse than him.

Questions: What did the farmer advise Miss Blomefield to do?
Answers: To try Beauty. If she didn’t like him, would take him back.

Questions: Who came to take Beauty to Miss Blomefield?
Answers: A young man.

Questions: What did the young man say when he saw Beauty?
Answers: He said it had a white foot and a white star like Black Beauty.

Questions: What did the Young man tell Black Beauty?
Answers: He told him that he was Joe Green.

Questions: What did Joe discover about Beauty?
Answers: He said that not everyone treated him well.

Questions: What did Joe tell Miss Blomefield about Beauty?
Answers: He told her that Beauty was one day Squire Gordon’s favourite horse

Questions: Was Beauty happy with Miss Blomefield?
Answers: Yes, he was happy to live in their place.

Questions: How long did he live with them?
Answers: He lived in that [lace for a year.

Questions: How did Joe look after Beauty?
Answers: He looked after him well.

Questions: How was Beauty’s work there and what did he feel?
Answers: He had easy work so he felt strong and healthy again.

Questions: How did the story end for Beauty?
Answers: His troubles were over and he lived happily.
